nav.div: Fairhaven Public Schools » Families & Students » Coronavirus Update

p.style: padding: 10px 0px; margin: 0px 0px 15px; caret-color: rgb(0, 0, 0); color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: "Fira Sans", sans-serif;

div.p: Fairhaven Public Schools' top priority is the health and safety of our students and staff. To ensure we are prepared for all situations, we have emergency procedures in place including infectious diseases. We are working to provide you regular, up-to-date information about the evolving situation.

p.style: padding: 10px 0px; margin: 0px 0px 15px; caret-color: rgb(0, 0, 0); color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: "Fira Sans", sans-serif;

div.p:
Please know we take this situation very seriously and we’re working around the clock to provide healthy safe school communities. The recent communication shared with Fairhaven families and community are below for your review.
External Resources:
MA Department of Health Website with up-to-date information
Guidance for Childcare Programs & K-12 Schools
Center for Disease Control Website
Town of Fairhaven Health Department page
Social Distancing: This is Not a Snow Day

div.div: March 20, 2020 Emergency School Committee Meeting Regarding COVID-19.

                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl21_divTabs_0","title":"4/11 Dr. Baldwin Message: My Sincere Hope","content":"

Dear Fairhaven School-community,

It is my sincere hope that our entire school community is safe and well. However, the reality is that this health crisis is affecting the personal, physical, social, emotional, and financial well being of everyone in our school community. As I reach out to you this afternoon, my message will attempt to integrate both hope and reality. 

I take very seriously my responsibility as our school leader to provide you with as much information as possible and to make decisions that need to be made. The driving force for my decision-making is to benefit the greater good for their long-term success. I do recognize that many of my decisions will not always be what some may want. 

I continue to approach this as a health crisis with an educational impact. In doing so the safety and well being of our greater school-community is my priority. However, it is with sincere hope and optimism that I share with you my vision for the end of the school year. 

At this week’s school committee meeting, they determined that the last day of school for the 2019 – 2020 school year is June 22, 2020. It is my sincere hope that after our return from April vacation we will begin to see the light of normalcy as we move into May. 

Nothing can replace the “brick and mortar,” teacher-led classes. Learning has its foundation in the relationships developed between learners and teachers, whether adults or children. There is no way to replicate this environment in a digital format in the middle of a pandemic.

Martin Luther King Jr. stated that,  “Faith is taking the first step even when you can't see the whole staircase.” The school committee’s decision to honor and continue April Vacation (April 20 – 24, 2020) provides us with the opportunity for this to potentially occur in June. 

It is with sincere hope that I will trade four days in June to reunite teachers and students for four days of digital learning at the peak of a pandemic. It is my sincere hope that our teachers and students can be reunited together again in the month of June for some period of time. 

Currently, Governor Baker has determined that all schools in the Commonwealth will remain closed through May 4, 2020. If we were to return on May 4, 2020, the end of the year activities would maintain their current schedules. Since March 13, 2020, the only information that has remained certain is uncertainty itself. As a result, we are proactively working on alternative potential dates for end of the year activities pushing as far back into June and corresponding with our last day on June 22, 2020. With that in mind, it is my sincere hope that the Fairhaven High School Class of 2020 can graduate on Sunday June 21, 2020 and that Fairhaven High School can have Junior Day on Friday June 19, 2020.

I began this narrative by attempting to integrate hope and reality. I have presented statements of sincere hope for our school community. I will continue to make decisions during this health crisis based upon the safety and well being of our greater school-community. My faith is that we all get to the top of the staircase. Please stay safe!


Dr. Baldwin","active":true,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl21_divTabs_1","title":"March 26, 2020: Closure Extended, Teaching & Learning Update","content":"
To our Fairhaven Public School Community: 

Yesterday the Governor of the Commonwealth officially extended the initial three-week school closure period through May 3, 2020. In anticipation of this decision, our district has been working tirelessly to determine what learning should look like during this time away from the classroom.

Our shared hope is that, in future years when children reflect on this time in their lives, what they will remember most are the positive connections they felt at an uncertain time. School is a special place - a sacred place. It is our continued belief that learning has its foundation in the relationships developed between learners and teachers, whether adults or children. There is no way to replicate this environment in a remote format in the middle of a pandemic over a month or two. However, it is our obligation to continue to do whatever we can, as best as we possibly can.

Holistic Needs of our School-Community

We are deeply concerned about the physical and emotional health of everyone in our school community. As such, we commit to planning and supporting learning that lessens stress and anxiety. Part of this commitment means developing the skills and tools necessary to evolve and prioritize these relationships. We have asked all of our educators to check in with their students. Our first obligation is to ensure that students feel safe and remain connected to their learning. 

In our commitment to these relationships, new content and grades are not a priority at this time. Our focus will be on reinforcing skills already taught this school year and applying and deepening these skills.

We recognize that there are countless challenges for identified learners who need specialized instruction and know that we will not be able to solve all of these challenges in the short term. As such, we will continue to focus on safety and connection while providing students with learning opportunities. 

Work to Adopt a Remote Teaching and Learning Model

We purposefully worked to prioritize our students’ and families’ needs first.  We want to thank you for your patience during this trying time.  Governor Baker has stated that, “Although schools must suspend in-person educational operations, staff should be planning for how best to equitably provide alternative access to student learning opportunities during this period and potentially beyond.”

In the last 13 days the Fairhaven Public Schools has:

    
        

            
            
Successfully launched a free lunch and breakfast program
            
        
        

            
            
Conducted a connectivity survey of all 2,000 students in the district
            
        
        

            
            
Had teachers make contact to check in on all of our students
            
        
        

            
            
Shared video(s) from teacher(s) to connect to students in a caring and light way
            
        
        

            
            
Sent home learning plans for all students for this week 
            
Learning plans included links to give students access to online tools that they already utilize at school
            
        
    






What to expect next:





    
        

            
            
Monday, March 30th: Look for next week's learning plan from your child(ren)’s teacher
            
        
        

            
            
Updates on a safe device deployment in the next week for children with no or limited access to technology
            
        
        

            
            
Update from Education Commissioner Riley in coming days, including guidance to be sure our long term plan meets his guidelines
            
        
        

            
            
New information on how we plan to help to support our students with special needs
            
        
        

            
            
New information on how we plan to help support our English Language Learners 
            
        
    






Keeping the Learning Alive

Students will be encouraged by their teachers to use materials sent via email or Google Classroom to keep the knowledge they have gained a priority while schools are closed. Recommended topics on weekly learning plans and assignments are meant to maintain content knowledge and keep the brain active. Students will not be given set deadlines during this time however we are working to have teachers send feedback to students as needed.

We understand how challenging these new norms are for your child(ren).  Please consider building a rough schedule with your child(ren) to set aside at least 1 hour of reading each day and at least 1 hour of other academic/learning assignments on the learning plan provided to you.  Creating some sort of schedule at home is a great strategy to keep students in a routine. In addition to the WGBH links provided by the Massachusetts Department of Education, we recommend families to continue encouraging reading of anything from books, magazines, NEWSela, or even subtitles on a television. 

We will continue to do whatever we can, as best as we possibly can. We understand and respect that your family must do whatever you can by prioritizing what fits best into your particular lives. We stand ready to be that constant that is there for you, however, for now, we will have to do so in a remote manner. Please continue to stay safe.





Respectfully,

Dr. Baldwin

Superintendent of Schools

","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl21_divTabs_2","title":"Grab and Go Meals: March 17, 2020","content":"






Good Afternoon,





Below is an update regarding school operations during our unexpected closure: 





2019 – 2020 Calendar

From the start of school through March 13, 2020, the Fairhaven Public Schools utilized one school cancellation day due to inclement weather. As a result, Monday through Thursday of this week will be treated as regular school cancellation days. These days will be made up in June, with the last day being June 22. The Commissioner of Education altered regulations so that makeup days will not exceed our scheduled 185th day of school. 





Doing the math, and understanding the fluidity of this situation, I am informing you that the 2019 – 2020 school year will not be the traditional 180 days in duration. Based upon the information at hand, the last scheduled day of school for the Fairhaven Public Schools is June 22, 2020.





Nutrition Services

Beginning on March 18th, Fairhaven Public Schools will provide “Grab and Go” meals during our district closure to any Fairhaven school-age child in need of lunch.  Each boxed “Grab and Go” meal contains (1) lunch and (1) breakfast for the next morning.  Meals can be picked up Monday through Friday from 11:30 am-1:00 pm at Elizabeth Hastings Middle School.   Please be aware that social distancing practices must be followed.  Please stay at least 6 feet away from others.  Also, hand sanitizer will be available on site.





Keeping the Learning Alive

We have been in constant contact with Massachusetts Commissioner of Education, Jeff Riley, and want to let you know that DESE is creating a statewide plan in terms of the educational resources that can be used as a supplement. DESE staff is currently vetting and compiling resources for districts to enhance their own resources. They have created a partnership with WGBH – which will become a part of their daily broadcasting schedule – this resource will roll out in the next day or two. DESE will be producing a letter that we will share with our families as soon as it is released.





Locally, we understand that nothing can replace the “brick and mortar,” teacher-led classes, however, we are in the process of unveiling a plan of enhancement activities and educational resources to be supportive to our families and students. It is our objective to get resources to supplement students during this extraordinary and challenging situation, but it is not intended to replace the normal school day. Our specific plan will be to do what we can, as best as we possibly can. We will be in communication with you about the specifics of this plan by the end of the week.





Coronavirus Update

As of today, there are no confirmed cases in Fairhaven. However, we continue to encourage strict adherence to health officials’ recommendations around social distancing, proper hygiene and the reporting of any flu-like symptoms to the proper officials. 





If you have any specific questions or concerns please contact:










Click here for the flyer: Grab n Go Flyer





Contact your building principal with any questions:
Fairhaven High School | akulak@fairhavenps.net
Elizabeth I. Hastings Middle School | nbettencourt@fairhavenps.net
Leroy L. Wood Elementary | yburnett@fairhavenps.net
East Fairhaven Elementary School | wweidenfeller@fairhavenps.net

","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl21_divTabs_3","title":"3-Week Closure: March 16, 2020","content":"

FPS Families and/or Guardians,

This evening, Governor Baker instituted a number of additional measures across the state to increase social distancing. One of those is to keep all public and private PK-12 schools across the state closed for the next three weeks (and a day). As we had already planned on a one-week closure, we are now extending that plan through Monday, April 6th.

Again, all schools and school activities are shut down until after Monday, April 6th.

As mentioned in prior communications, we are working on plans to ensure that all students receive access to positive academic experiences throughout the closure by providing a number of “distance learning” opportunities through “at-home” learning ideas on our website. 

We recognize that this is a uncertain and difficult time for all of us, and it is our intent to stay strong and provide all we can to our students, staff, and families.

Adjustments to that plan and/or the specifics of educational plans will be announced through email and on our website as soon as they are known.

Thank you,

Dr. Baldwin



","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl21_divTabs_4","title":"School Closing Update: March 13, 2020","content":"

We appreciate your patience as we have been working over the past few weeks to deal with the rapidly-changing novel coronavirus, COVID-19, and its impact on our community.  

We are confident in the ongoing communication and information that we receive from our local and state health officials. At this time, there have been no confirmed cases in Fairhaven. However, we understand the heightened concern and uncertainty around this evolving and unprecedented situation. 

The health, safety, and wellbeing of our students, faculty, staff and families is our top priority. The one constant that can provide order, predictability, and structure to our daily lives is the institution of our schools. The routines that this institution affords us are teaching and learning, a safe and supportive environment, predictable meals, as well as health and counseling services.  

We understand circumstances like these create difficult decision-making situations for families. In partnership with the local school districts in our region, we have made the decision to close the Fairhaven Public Schools for at least one (1) week, effective immediately. As such, the Fairhaven Public Schools will be closed Monday, March 16th - Friday, March 20th. 

This closure includes all student activities. School days will be made up in the same fashion as snow days in late June. However, make-up days will not exceed our 185th day of school. Our last day of school will be June 22, 2020. 

A status update relative to next steps will be distributed to our Fairhaven community on Friday, March 20, 2020. 






WHAT WE KNOW TO DATE:



    
As of Friday, March 13, Fairhaven Public Schools will close for one-week to evaluate the situation at hand and next step actions.    
    
No students, staff or faculty will be allowed on any school campus during this closure, with the exception of custodial staff.
    
Within the past week, district leadership has participated in multiple meetings and statewide conference calls. 
    
Town of Fairhaven Emergency Management officials met earlier this week and have a clear, organized plan, should the threat to the Town of Fairhaven increase. 
    
As of March 10, the Governor declared a State of Emergency in Massachusetts.
    
As of March 11, the World Health Organization has declared COVID-19 a Global Pandemic.
    
    
On March 11, we participated in a conference call with Massachusetts Department of Health.
    
    
On March 11, we met face to face with Commissioner of Education Jeff Riley. 
    
    
On March 13, we participated in a conference call about COVID-19 with the Department of Public Health (DPH) and the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE).
    
    
We continue to process the information that we receive from these interactions as well as input from the Center for Disease Control (CDC) and medical experts. We listen and adhere to the recommendations received from our state leaders on the situation.
    
    
Per our daily update from our local health agent, there are no known confirmed cases of the COVID-19 in our schools. We have open and ongoing communication with our trusted health officials who are consulting with us about any concerns with COVID-19. 
    
If you or your child have been medically quarantined, please the Fairhaven Board of Health at 508-979-4023 ext. 125


WHAT YOU CAN DO

    
Wash your hands often with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds  
    
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth  
    
Cover your coughs and sneezes
    
Stay away from people who are sick and stay home when you are sick
    
If you have a fever or flu-like symptoms, please stay home and seek appropriate medical attention  


WHERE TO GET YOUR INFORMATION

    
CDC website
    
www.mass.gov/2019coronavirus
    
Town of Fairhaven Health Department Page 


Fairhaven Public Schools continues to carefully monitor the guidance from DPH, CDC and other public health agencies and will follow their recommendations as advised. We will update our response according to guidance from our federal and state public health partners. 

If you have a particular concern about your child’s health, please don’t hesitate to contact your school nurse or your child’s pediatrician. 




















All-Call Message:

Good afternoon, this is Dr. Baldwin, Superintendent of Schools. We are aware of growing concerns around the novel Coronavirus 2019, and we are confident in the ongoing communication and information that we receive from our local and state health officials. 

At this time, there have been no confirmed cases in Fairhaven. However, we understand the heightened concern and uncertainty around this evolving and unprecedented situation, and understand the burden of difficult decision-making for families. 

As a result, in partnership with the local school districts in our region, we have made the decision to close the Fairhaven Public Schools for at least one (1) week, effective immediately. As such, the Fairhaven Public Schools will be closed Monday, March 16th - Friday, March 20th.




Following this call, you will receive additional information via email. 



","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl21_divTabs_5","title":"March 13, 2020 Update","content":"

We are reaching out to our school community during this unprecedented period of uncertainty and concern around Coronavirus (COVID-19). Since the onset of this issue, we have been participating in every available conference call and/or guidance from federal, state and local officials. We take our responsibilities very seriously to provide you with as much information as possible and to make decisions that need to be made. 

It is an understatement that this situation is evolving, as a result, we have to be prepared for the possibility of changes with little to no notice. We may cancel an event on a days notice. We prefer not to handle things this way, but it is critical for us to follow a consistent, logical and informed decision-making process in dealing with this situation.

While we feel like we have a good handle on information, we have a conference call with the Commissioner of Education and Massachusetts Department of Public Health (DPH) tomorrow, Friday, March 13, at 8:30AM and will provide you with a more detailed update by the end of the day tomorrow. 

The information below is to provide you with an update on our dealings with COVID-19. It is with the utmost of sincerity that I wish you all to please be safe.


TO DATE:



    
Within the past week, district leadership has participated in multiple meetings and statewide conference calls. 
    
Town of Fairhaven Emergency Management officials met earlier this week and have a clear, organized plan, should the threat to Fairhaven increase. You can watch their video update here.
    
As of March 10, the Governor declared a State of Emergency in Massachusetts. 
    
As of March 11, the World Health Organization has declared COVID-19 a Global Pandemic.
    
On March 11, we met face to face with Commissioner of Education Jeff Riley. 
    
On March 13, we are scheduled to have another conference call about COVID-19 with the Department of Public Health (DPH) and the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE). 
    
We continue to process the information that we receive from these interactions as well as input from the Center for Disease Control (CDC) and medical experts. We listen and adhere to the recommendations received from our state leaders on the situation.
    
As of today, March 12, there are no known confirmed cases of the Coronavirus in our schools.


","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl21_divTabs_6","title":"February 2020 Update","content":"

 We recognize the concerns expressed around the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19). 

According to the MA Department of Public Health (DPH) and the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the risk to Fairhaven remains low at this time. We want to use this opportunity to assure you that we take this issue and all others around the health and safety of our students, staff, and families very seriously. We have been and will continue to monitor the latest updates regarding COVID-19. In addition, we will continue to take the steps necessary to keep our students and staff safe and healthy.

It’s also important to be educated on the facts about COVID-19 in MA. As of now, here’s what we know from our trusted state and local Health partners:

    
At this time, Massachusetts has one confirmed case of COVID-19 and the risk to our residents remains low.   
    
At the same time, the risk of the influenza virus is very high. 
    
As of this writing, it is extremely unlikely that anyone who has traveled to mainland China within the past 14 days would be at school.    
    
Many of the precautions that help prevent colds and the flu can help protect against other respiratory viruses.  


As recommended by the MPH and CDC, we have been focused on the flu and other common communicable diseases using the same preventative measures that would be used for COVID-19. Please know that FPS custodial staff are following our regular procedures, and continue to be diligent cleaning and disinfecting our schools using approved products, especially door knobs and other high touch areas. As a reminder, we ask that you continue to follow these precautions at school and home:

    
Wash your hands often with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds
    
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth
    
Cover your coughs and sneezes
    
    
If you have a fever or flu-like symptoms, please stay home and seek appropriate medical attention  


Fairhaven Public Schools continues to carefully monitor the guidance from DPH, CDC and other public health agencies and will follow their recommendations as advised. We will update our response according to guidance from our federal and state public health partners.  

If you would like to stay up-to-date on the Commonwealth’s response to the COVID-19 outbreak, please visit www.mass.gov/2019coronavirus.




If you have a particular concern about your child’s health, please don’t hesitate to contact your school nurse or your child’s pediatrician.
